title: Legislative Council Question No. 8 (Written Reply)
question_text: Asked by: Dr Hon YEUNG Sum Replied by: Secretary for Health and Welfare Question: It is reported that the World Health Organization has pointed out that obesity will be the major health problem for mankind in the next century. In this connection, will the Government inform this Council : (a) whether statistics are available on the weight to height ratios of the population in Hong Kong; if so, of the figures as compared with the standard ratios recommended by the World Health Organization; if not, whether it will conduct surveys in this regard; (b) how it helps the

if not, whether it will conduct surveys in this regard; (b) how it helps the
public prevent obesity or provides treatment to members of the public who suffer from
obesity; and (c) of the plans in place
to curb the increase in the number of obesity cases and prevent obesity-related diseases;
and the resources involved in carrying out each of such plans?
reply_text:
Madam President, (a) A group of experts
from the University of Hong Kong, the Department of Health and the Hospital Authority have
conducted a study during the years of 1994 to 1996 on the cardiovascular risk factors in
Hong Kong. The results of the study indicated that, according to the criteria recommended
by the World Health Organization for adult population (Body Mass Index [weight (kg) /
(height (m))<sup>2</sup>] exceeding 30), 5% of men and 7% of women in Hong Kong aged 25-74

were obese. As for students, any student whose body weight is more than 20% above the
median weight for height of the local students will be diagnosed as obese. In 1997/98
academic year, about 12% of students attended the Student Health Service Centres were
found to be obese. According to the figures
released by the World Health Organization, the prevalence of obesity in adults is 10% to
25% in most countries of Western Europe, 20% to 25% in some countries in the Americas, and

up to 40% in some countries in Eastern Europe. (b) Prevention is always
better than treatment for all illnesses, including obesity. The Department of Health and
the Hospital Authority thus emphasize assisting the public to prevent obesity. This
involves three aspects of services : Health Promotion Services
-- Prevention of obesity is one of the core themes of the health promotion programmes.
Publicity and educational activities are organized by the Department of Health and the
Hospital Authority to raise public awareness of obesity and to publicize means of
preventing it. Health education materials such as pamphlets, videos, exhibition boards,

preventing it. Health education materials such as pamphlets, videos, exhibition boards,
CD-ROMs and Video Compact Discs have been produced, and disseminated through public
clinics and hospitals in all districts, to encourage the choice of a balanced diet and
appropriate exercises. Private practitioners can obtain health education pamphlets free of
charge for distribution to their patients. The Department of Health’s Student Health
Service also promotes healthy lifestyle among students through the Service’s
newsletter "Colourful Bridge" to schools. Special training courses have been
organized by the Department of Health for teachers, students, women and elderly as health

organized by the Department of Health for teachers, students, women and elderly as health
ambassadors who will in turn help promoting healthy living in the community. Since 1994,
more than 4500 health ambassadors have successfully completed training. They had organized
about 2000 health education activities with an attendance of over one million. Screening Services –
Children, students, women and elderly attending the Maternal and Child Health Centres,
Student Health Service Centres, Woman Health Centres and Elderly Health Centres
respectively are screened for obesity by the Department of Health. Clients found to have

respectively are screened for obesity by the Department of Health. Clients found to have
abnormal body weight will be counselled by nurses and doctors at the Centres. Similarly,
the Hospital Authority will screen their patients for obesity. Support Services -- For
clients found to be obese in the Department of Health’s respective Centres or General
Out-patient Clinics, counselling will be offered to them by dieticians or health staff.
Support groups and keep fit classes are also organized for them. Where necessary, clients
are referred to Hospital Authority specialists for follow-up to ascertain whether there is

are referred to Hospital Authority specialists for follow-up to ascertain whether there is
any underlying reason for the obesity. The Hospital Authority, with the help of a
mutlidisciplinary team, will explain to the patients the reasons for obesity and the
consequences on their image and activites. Any pharmacological treatment or surgical
operation is rarely adopted for curing obesity, because the best method is still either
the adoption of a healthy lifestyle or the curing of any underlying illnesses.
